message.content: This question requires knowledge about the function of plant roots and their impact on rocks. Plant roots release organic acids that help break down rocks over time. As the roots develop and grow, they continue to exert pressure on the surrounding rocks, causing them to break down further. Option (A) is incorrect because decay refers to the decomposition of organic matter, not the breakdown of rocks. Option (B) is incorrect because as roots grow old, they become less effective at breaking down rocks. Option (D) is incorrect because the roots do not decrease, but rather continue to develop and grow.

This question requires basic knowledge about the role of plant roots in breaking down rocks. When plant roots grow, they exert pressure on the rocks they come into contact with, causing the rocks to crack and break down over time. Option (A) is incorrect because decay refers to the process of organic matter breaking down, not rocks. Option (B) is incorrect because the aging process of plant roots does not directly contribute to the breaking down of rocks. Option (D) is incorrect because decrease does not describe the action of plant roots on rocks.

This question requires basic knowledge about the role of plant roots in breaking down rocks. Plant roots release chemicals that help break down rocks through a process called weathering. As the roots develop and grow, they secrete acids and enzymes that break down the minerals in rocks, eventually contributing to the decomposition of rocks and soil formation. Option (A) is incorrect because decay refers to the process of organic matter breaking down, not the actions of plant roots on rocks. Option (B) is incorrect because plant roots do not grow old, they continue to grow and develop as the plant grows. Option (D) is incorrect because the roots of a plant do not decrease, they continue to expand and grow.
